advice: The 'Space Saver' from a Maxima or Altima often fits the Z/G cars if you don't have the Brembo brakes. If you have Brembos, you need the specific 18-inch spare from a G35 Coupe or 350Z Track model.

BMW spares are plentiful. A 3-Series spare (E46) is a great trunk-saver for other 5x120 cars. Watch out for the E39 5-Series—it has a huge hub bore (74.1mm) and won't fit other BMWs without rings, and other BMW wheels won't fit IT at all.

The 'Miata Daisy' spare is legendary, but for a cheap replacement, grab a 4x100 donut from a 90s Corolla or Civic. Just check the center hole—Honda hubs are slightly bigger (56.1mm) than Mazda (54.1mm), so a Honda spare fits a Miata, but a Miata spare won't fit a Civic!

Mustang spares are easy to find. They share the bolt pattern with Nissan/Toyota, but the Ford hub is HUGE (70.5mm). This means a Mustang wheel fits almost anything (Nissan, Toyota, etc.), but nothing else fits a Mustang.

Toyota uses a 60.1mm hub bore. This is smaller than Nissan (66.1) and Ford (70.5). You CANNOT use a Toyota spare on a Nissan or Ford, but you CAN use a Nissan or Ford spare on a Toyota (it will just be lug-centric, which is fine for a temporary spare).
Honda uses a 64.1mm hub. Similar to Toyota, you can use a Nissan (66.1) or Ford (70.5) spare on a Honda, but a Honda spare won't fit a Nissan. Acura TL/TSX spares are great donors for 5-lug Civics.

Subaru spares are tricky because of AWD. You MUST ensure the spare tire diameter matches your other tires within 1/4 inch, or you will destroy your center differential. Note on Hubs: VW hubs are 57.1mm, Subaru is 56.1mm. A VW spare fits a Subaru (loose), but a Subaru spare WON'T fit a VW.

The 'Universal Asian' size. Hyundai, Kia, Mazda, and Mitsubishi all use the 67.1mm hub. This is slightly larger than Nissan (66.1) and Toyota (60.1). A spare from this group fits almost ANY 5-lug Asian car (except Honda/Subaru), but Nissan/Toyota spares are too small to fit these cars.
Mercedes and newer Audis use 66.6mm hubs. Older VWs/Audis use 57.1mm. A Mercedes spare fits a VW (with a gap), but a VW spare won't fit a Mercedes. Always check caliper clearance on German cars!
The 'Ford/Volvo Alliance' means spares from a Volvo S40/V50/S60 often fit Ford Focus (2012+) and Fusion. Jaguar also uses this pattern. It's a weird size, so grab one if you see it.

The universal truck pattern. Chevy Silverado, Toyota Tacoma/Tundra, and Nissan Titan all share the bolt pattern. However, hub bores vary wildly. A Chevy wheel (78mm hub) won't fit a Toyota (106mm hub), but a Toyota wheel fits almost anything.
